translation.author: Repetier
translation.t: Send emergency stop to printer. You may need to reset the printer for a restart!
Reset output. After some wait, I got only $1
Receiving only error messages. Stopped communication.
Do you realy want to delete all settings for $1?
From Arduino 1 on the receiving cache was reduced from 127 to 63 bytes!

The printer settings always correspond to the selected printer at the top. They are stored with every OK or apply. To create a new printer, just enter a new printer name and press apply. The new printer starts with the last settings selected.
You can run a filter program after each slicing action. The filter will be run on the G-Code produced by the slicer. Use #in and #out to insert the input and output filenames as parameter.
Go to Park Position after Job/Kill
Use Ping-Pong Communication (Send only after ok)

Hint: You are allowed to move the extruder around and to extrude filament in order to change the filament or refill the nozzle if oozing occured. The host will restore the position at the start of the pause for you.
No new updates available. You are using the latest version.

This software was developed for controlling RepRap like 3D-printer. It is best used with Repetier-Firmware, which supports all features. Other printer firmware like Marlin, Teacup, Sprinter or 5D GCode interpreter should work with proper settings.

I could not find the generated G-code file.
Possible reasons: - the slicer had an error and didn't finish slicing. Check log output. - the slicer stored the file with an unexpected filename.

In the work directory, the logfile and temporary files for slicing are stored. If logging is enabled, there will be a file repetier.log after the program is closed. Starting the program will delete the old log file! The logfile conatins all communication with the printer, even if disabled in the log view. Logging changes are active after next start.

The shape of the filament is computed either by layer height and width over thickness or from the filament diameter, width over thickness and E values in the G-Code. The second version gives better results, if the layer height changes, which can happen in newer Skeinforge versions.

This save function is meant to generate G-code files that can be run from a sd card. For that reason it can add the start and end code along with the regular finish commands like they are executed during a direct print from the host. All comments and host commands get removed! If you only want to save the G-code in your editor, use the save icon there.
Run Selected File / Continue Paused Print
Your firmware doesn't implement file delete or has an unknown implementation.
You can remove the sd card.
Leave blank to use the bundled or system version.

With these settings, you are able to use different versions of Slic3r. You can get new versions from http://www.slic3r.org The minimum version required is 0.9.0. Leave all fields blank to simply use the bundled version.
Leave blank to use guessed location.
Settings stored to running config. Write Changes to EEPROM?
Last slice job still running. Slicing of new job is canceled.
$1 slicing process killed on user request.
Select the profiles subdirectory in the skeinforge configuration directory. This is normally HOME/.skeinforge/profiles. For some custom versions like SFACT the path may vary.

If you have pypy installed, Skeinforge slices will run 3-4 times faster. If you don't have pypy installed, leave it blank and the python interpreter will be used instead. You can get the lastest pypy at http://www.pypy.org/
The working directory determines, where SFACT will store profiles!
Could not get a connection to the update server!

The min and max values define the possible range of extruder coordinates. These coordinates can be negative and outside the print bed. Bed left/front define the coordinates where the printbed itself starts. By changing the min/max values you can even move the origin in the center of the print bed, if supported by firmware.
Pypy or Python interpreter not found.
Use correct normals (looks better, needs more memory)
Some heaters are still on. Shall I disable them?
At least one object is outside the printable area. Abort slicing?
One or more objects files are changed. Reload objects?
The connection failed with the following error: $1. Make sure your printer is connected, enabled and connection data is set correct. Open printer settings?
Enable parallel mode in top view
Object is non-manifold. Slicing may produce wrong results. Please repair object file first.
Are you sure you want to delete job $1?
The Job state will be saved once the current layer is completed. You can also force saving the job state now, or resume printing.
Normal correction not possible for non-manifold meshes.
Slic3r is separate, external program, which can be started separately. For further informations, please visit the following webpage: http://www.slic3r.org
Skeinforge is separate, external program, which can be started separately. For further informations, please visit the following webpage: http://fabmetheus.crsndoo.com/
Filename contains illegal chars or is too long. Don't use more then 26 chars.
The slicer created a new g-code file. Shall I load it?

The watch directory shows the file types defined above. Separate multiple types with a semicolon like "g;gcode". Every printer has it's own directory setting, which gets watched. If a file is new or changed, when you switch to Repetier-Host it will show the files and highlight them for fast import.
Import of eeprom data failed. Invalid file format.
Enable anti-aliasing if possible (slows down visualization, restart required)

The object is not manifold. This essentially means, that it is not watertight. This normally causes problems during slicing, resulting in unwanted results. We strongly advice to repair the file. One free repair service is: https://netfabb.azurewebsites.net
CuraEngine is separate, external program developed by David Braam. For more informations visit https://www.ultimaker.com

Repetier-Informer is a smartphone app that allows you to receive push notifications. In the app you can create new groups or use shared groups. Enter here the group you want the host to send messages to. All members of the group will receive the send messages.
Print for printer $1 started. The print will be finished around $2.
Print for printer $1 is paused. Message: $2
Print for printer $1 is finished. Printing time: $2. Lines send to printer: $3
Print for printer $1 was stopped before it was finished.
Slicing for printer $1 is now finished.
A fatal error for printer printer $1 occured. Message: $2

CuraEngine only supports one extruder diameter and flow value, because it assumes identical extruders. If you have a multi-extruder setup with different values, the values from the first extruder are used for all. Print temperatures are set in the start g-code, so using different temperatures for different materials is no problem. For cooling the highest values of all extruders are used.
Target group id from your app.
Optional. Gets added to title of send messages.
With this speed the filament is retracted. Higher retraction speed works better, but if it is too high it can lead to filament grinding.
Distance to retract. Set 0 for no retraction. Typical values range from 2 mm for direct extruders to 7 mm for bowden extruders.
Layer height of the bottom layer. A thicker first layer compensates irregularities from the printer bed better.
Sinks the object into the platform. This can be used for objects that do not have a flat bottom and thus create too small first layer.
For this length the different colors or materials overlap with multi-extrusion, so that they connect better together.
With this speed travel moves are done. This can be quite fast, but if the value is too high, some printer can miss steps.
Print speed for the first layer. It should be slower to stick better to the printer bed.
With this speed the infill is printed. With faster moves you can reduce printing time, but it can reduce printing quality.
With this speed the outer perimeter is printed. Printing with lower speed improves the skin quality. A too big difference between inner and outer perimeter printing speed can reduce the quality.
With this speed the inner perimeter is printed. Faster printing than the outer perimeter will reduce printing time. The speed should be between infill speed and outer perimeter speed.
Minimum time for printing one layer. The time should be high enough to cool down the layer. If printing speed is too fast, it will slow down to use this time for one layer.
Activates cooling fan while printing. This can significantly improve the print quality, especially for PLA, bridging and overhangs.

With the layer height in millimeters you will set the print resolution in z-direction. Lower values increase print quality but will take more printing time. Normal values are between 0.1 mm and 0.4 mm.
The thickness of the outside shell in horizontal direction. In combination with the nozzle size the number of perimeter lines is determined.
Retract the filament when the nozzle is moving over a none-printed area. This helps to reduce or terminate stringing.

This sets the amount of solid layers of the top and bottom. Depending on your infill density, you should increase the thickness, so the infill does not shine through and to increase the print quality. 1 mm is normally a good value.

Herewith you determine the infill density. Massive objects have 100%, empty objects 0%. The higher the infill is, the more stable the object is. With a lower infill you can save a lot of printing time and filament. Normal values are between 20% and 30%, if you do not require a high stability.
Print speed for all parts that have no separate speed setting.
The temperature depends on the used filament and the printer. Many filament manufacturers specify a range of the optimum print temperatures.

Type of the builded support structure.
"None" disables support.
"Touching bed" is the most common setting. It will only create support where the support structure will touch the bed.
"Everywhere" creates support creates even on top of parts of the model.

Helps to improve the adhesion of the object on the bed.
"None" disables disables this function.
"Brim" adds a single layer high area around your object, which can easily be cut of afterwards. Brim is required if objects warp at the edges.
"Raft" adds a thick raster below the object and a thin interface between this and the object, which can be removed after printing. This is required if you have a bumpy bed or such a small object, that it would not stick well during the print.
The diameter of the filament should be specified as precisely as possible.
The extruded filament amount gets multiplied with this value. Normally this should be 100%.
Minimum travel distance to activate retraction.

If there is a way to move the head to the target point without leaving the current object, that path is taken. If disabled, always the straight line to the destination point is taken, which can cause strings.

Minimum amount of extrusion before next retract is done. If a retraction is needed before this minimum is reached, retraction will be ignored. If you retract too often at the same place, the filament may get flat and block the extruder.
The head is lifted by this distance while retracting. This has some positive effects for printers with fast z-axis like delta printers.
The skirt is a line on the first layer drawn around the object. This helps to prime your extruder and you can see if the object fits on your bed. Set 0 to disable skirt.
The distance between the skirt line and the model.
The minimum length of the skirt line. If the length is not reached, additional skirt lines are added. If the skirt line count is set to 0, this is ignored.
The height at which the fan is turned on completely. For the layers below the fan speed is scaled down linearly with the fan off for the first layer.

This is the minimum fan speed for cooling. If layer time is lower than minimum layer time, the printing speed gets slowed down and fan speed gets interpolated between min. and max. fan speed depending on the slow down.
This is the maximum fan speed for cooling. It is reached, if layer time is reducing speed by more than 50%.
Lift the head if printing with minimum speed is faster than minimum layer time after layer is printed.

The minimum layer time can slow down the printer so much that the printed filament can start to ooze. This minimum speed protects against this. Even if the printer slows down, it can not get slower than this speed.
Creates a solid top surface. If disabled, the set infill will be used. Useful for vases defined as solid volumes.
Creates a solid bottom surface. If disabled, the set infill will be used. Useful for buildings defined as solid volumes.
This defines the overlap of the infill and the walls. There should be a slight overlap so that the walls connect firmly the the infill.

Choose between support pattern:
"Grid" is very strong and can come off in one piece. Sometimes it is too strong.
"Lines" are single walled lines that break off one at a time. This is more work to remove, but it is less strong and works better on tricky prints.
The minimum angle that overhangs need to get support. 0° is horizontal, 90° is vertical.
Density of the support structure. Less material gives weaker support which is easier to remove. 15% is a good average.
Distance of the support material and the object in x/y directions. 0.8 mm is a good distance so that the support does not stick to the object.
Distance from the top/bottom of the support to the object. A small gap makes it easier to remove the support.
This turns a solid object into a single walled object, where z continuously increases to create a seamless surface. Ideal for vases.
The width of the brim. With larger brim the objects stick better to the bed, but it reduces your effective print area.
This is an extra raft area around your object when raft is enabled. A larger raft area will create a stronger raft, but it reduces your effective print area.
This is the distance of the raft center lines.
This is the thickness of the base layer.
This is the width of the base layer lines.
This is the thickness of the interface layer.
This is the width of the interface layer lines.
This is the gap between the raft and the object. The bigger the gap is, the easier you can remove the object, but you still need a distance, that sticks well enough to fix the object while printing.
Surface layers are the top layers of the raft. They have 100% infill to give you a plane surface for your print.

This advanced option adds all parts of the model together. The result is usually that internal cavaties disappear. Depending on the model this can be intended or not. Enabling this option is at your own risk. Type-A is dependent on the model normals and tries to keep some internal holes intact. Type-B ignores all internal holes and only keeps the outside shape per layer.

This advanced option adds all parts of the model together. The result is usually that internal cavaties disappear. Depending on the model this can be intended or not. Enabling this option is at your own risk. Type-A is dependent on the model normals and tries to keep some internal holes intact. Type-B ignores all internal holes and only keeps the outside shape per layer.

This advanced option keeps all the open bits of the model intact. Normally Cura tries to stitch up small holes and remove everything with big holes, but this option keeps bits that are not properly part of anything and just goes with whatever is left. This option is usually not what you want, but it might enable you to slice models otherwise failing to produce proper paths. As with all advanced options, results may vary. Use at your own risk.

Extensive stitching tries to fix up open holes in the model by closing the hole with touching polygons. This algorithm is computationally intensive and increases slicing time. As with all advanced options, results may vary. Use at your own risk.
Select a descriptive name to save.

"Automatic" selects lines or grids according to the density.
"Grid" gives a stable structure.
"Lines" are parallel and closer together.
"Concentric Lines" gives lines with reduced outline.

The wipe tower is a tower printed an every layer when switching between nozzles. The old nozzle is wiped off on the tower before the new nozzle is used to print the second color. The new nozzle gets primed on the tower, so that the new filament prints correctly on the object.
The ooze shield is a 1 line thick shell around the object which stands a few mm from the object. This shield catches any oozing from the unused nozzle in dual-extrusion.
Retraction distance when switching between the nozzles. Set 0 for no retraction at all.

The amount of filament material put in the wipe and prime tower. This is done in volume because in general you want to extrude a certain amount of volume to get the extruder going, independent an the layer height. With thinner layers, your tower gets bigger.

The assumed air gap between raft and object from the second layer of the object. Ideally, this value is 0. The assumption is, that the air gap after the first layer of the object is 0, since the first layer falls on the raft and so closing the gap.
Overrides the above selected Slic3r settings with the values ​​indicated below.
Replaces the values ​​listed below with the values ​​defined in the configurations selected above.
Adds support structures there where they are needed for printing.
Activates cooling fan while printing. This can significantly improve the print quality, especially for PLA, bridging and overhangs.

With the layer height in millimeters you will set the print resolution in z-direction. Lower values increase print quality but will take more printing time. Normal values are between 0.1 mm and 0.4 mm.

Herewith you determine the infill density. Massive objects have 100%, empty objects 0%. The higher the infill is, the more stable the object is. With a lower infill you can save a lot of printing time and filament. Normal values are between 20% and 30%, if you do not require a high stability.
This item selects the fill pattern of the inner infill.
This item selects the fill pattern of the shell.
Printer has a Mixing Extruder (one nozzle for all colors)
Invert movement direction for manual control:
Some printers use a switchable power supply, which can be turned on and off with this function.
Turns off the operating current for all motors. This can change the position of the extruder. As soon as a movement is initiated, the current for the corresponding motors turns on.
Moves the extruder to the park position.
Sends the script $1 to the printer. You can view and modify the scripts by right clicking the button.
This changes the current print speed. All speeds are multiplied by this value. The flow rate has this not be changed. Please note that high printing speeds can adversely affect print quality.
Allows you to change the flow rate, ie the amount of the extruded filament. A higher value gives a fatter printed line.
This controls the fan speed. Effective cooling improves the print quality, especially for overhangs and bridges.
This controls the heated bed temperature. Typical temperatures for PLA are between 50°C and 60°C, for ABS between 100°C and 120°C, depending on the bed coating.
This controls the extruder temperature. Typical temperatures for PLA are between 180°C and 220°C, for ABS between 240°C and 260°C, depending on filament and extruders.
Type of connection to the printer. Most printers use a serial connection. The virtual connection provides a virtual printer for testing.

Select the port that belongs to your printer. If you do not know the port, remove the USB cable to your printer and click "Refresh Ports", remember the list that appears here in the dropdown menu. Now connect the printer to your computer and update the list again. Your printer will operate under the newly added port. If there appears no new port, you have not installed the correct printer driver.

The speed your printer communicates. The most common speeds are 115200 and 250000. You will get a connection with an incorrect value, but the communication will not work and the printer receives no commands. This is the most common source of error for connection problems to the printer.

The transfer protocol to exchange data between host and printer. The binary protocol is the best and fastest, but it works only with the Repetier- Firmware. "Autodetect" selects the best method automatically.

Many boards allow to reset the board by changing the signal of the DTR or RTS pin. Basically, it is advantageous to restart the printer an a new connection, because this eliminates possible problems during connection. Some printers do not support this, in which case you should disable this feature.
This determines what happens when the emergency stop is pressed. Since it takes some time until the emergency stop command is received, you should combine the emergency with stop is reset.

To prevent tiny breaks during printing, the host sends multiple commands in simultaneously. You must enter the number of characters, the printer can definitely remember, so that the printer is not overloaded. Most printers provide 127 bytes, but some provide only 63 bytes. If you receive many communication error during, this value is probably too large.
For ping-pong communication there is always only one instruction on the way to the printer. This communication is much slower, so this option should be disabled if possible.
With this IP address the printer can be reached.
The port which the printer is reachable.
Simulated printer connection speed. From 250000 no waiting time is installed, for smaller values ​​appropriate breaks are inserted.
At this speed, the extruder moves with manual control in X and Y direction.
At this speed, the extruder moves with manual control in Z direction.
At this speed, the filament is extruded with manual control.
At this speed, the filament is retracted with manual control.
This extruder temperature is proposed when connecting the printer.
This heated bed temperature is proposed when connecting the printer.
This is required for temperature control and should be enabled.
Removes the log entries for temperature requests, so that the log file will be clearer.
Here you can specify how often the temperatures of the extruder and a heated bed get queried.
When parking, the extruder is brought to this X position.
When parking, the extruder is brought to this Y position.
The extruder is lifted for parking at this distance.

Sends the remaining print time or estimated time of completion of the print job. This is displayed in the host in the status bar and can be changed by clicking on the time between the remaining time and end time.
Turns off the extruder after the completion of the print job and when you press the emergency stop.
Turns off the motors after the completion of the print job and when you press the emergency stop.
Turns off the heated bed after the completion of the print job and when you press the emergency stop.

This increases the calculated printing time by this amount. This is necessary because the printer can not hold the speed in the corners and brakes accordingly. In this way a more accurate estimate of printing time possible, but this always varies by object and slicer settings.
Moves the extruder after the completion of the print job and when you press the emergency stop in the park position.
This reverses the movement direction of the selected axis for the manual control.
Here, you specify the number of extruders of your printer.
Here you enter the maximum extruder temperature that you can specify in the manual control. So you can avoid accidental overheating of the extruder.
Here you enter the maximum heated bed temperature that you can specify in the manual control. So you can avoid accidental overheating of the heated bed.
If you use a mixing extruder, where all colors are printed with the same nozzle, please enable this option.
Self-chosen name, which is used in object placement.
This offset is added to the filament temperatures. This allows you to use different extruder with the same filament settings.
The offset of the extruder in X direction for multiple extruders, if they are not configured within the firmware.
The offset of the extruder in Y direction for multiple extruders, if they are not configured within the firmware.
This filament color is used for the preview.
Here you can set your printer type.
Here you can set where the extruder is after homing.

This value can be used from Slicers to limit printing speed based on required volume throughput. Normally you can print around 12mm³/s. The higher the speed goes, the more heating and force is needed to push the filament grough the nozzle.
Print setting with that name already exists. Did not save.
Filament setting with that name already exists. Did not save.
The slicer also uses parameters set in "Printer-Settings"->"Extruders"!
Adds the above link to any message. E.g. a web enabled webcam url.
Print over sd card on printer $1 started.
Print over sd card on printer $1 finished.

For a better adhesion to the bed, it is often advantageous for the first layer to extrude more filament and thereby become wider. Here you can set how much wider the baseline compared to conventional extrusion is. The line density is adjusted accordingly.
The print on $1 will be finished around $2.
Object arrangement has changed since last slice. Really start this job?
Speed for outer full infill. Allows you to do faster internal infill without decreasing outer surface quality.
Global api key or api key of a user with print permissions.

This connector allows direct connection to a running Repetier-Server running on this or a remotely reachable device.To make it connect, enter the servers ip/hostname and port as well as the api key. You can use the global api key or the api key of a existing user with print permissions. Connect will then connect to the server instead of the printer directly. You can disconnect and reconnect any time, even while printing!
Defines if perimeter or infill gets printed first,
No port available for autoselect. Please connect your printer first!
You need at minumum version $1 of Repetier-Server to connect.
You are connected with an other printer. Please close connection first to continue.
Authorization with Server failed. Please check your Api Key.
Could not connect to server. Please verify IP number and port and check if server is enabled.
Most settings were pulled from the server and saved. Some settings are not available and were left unchanged.
Server has no printers defined. Can not connect. Please define first at least one printer and try again.
Auto Position Object when new Object is Added
You have a running job. Closing the connection will ruin your print. Close anyway?
Flips the buttons for x and y movements in manual control.
A fatal error on the printer side stopped the printer until the error is fixed. Printer message:
